message: WATCH THIS: CBS This Morning asked 3 families (with 3 very different income levels) for their tax returns & found that all of them would receive tax relief next year because of the tax reform bill that Congress just passed.
Happy New Year! May God bless you this new year!

Tonight, I appeared on CNN’s Erin Burnett OutFront to discuss Russian cyber hacking and President Obama’s sanctions against Russia. For a long time, the Russians have been engaged in hacking to influence elections all over Europe and Asia. This is not new. We need a consistent cyber strategy that governs our response to cyber threats wherever they exist.

We are back in action in Washington, DC this week. Be sure to follow me on Instagram (@SenatorLankford) to catch all behind-the-scenes photos of swearing-in activities. Also, tune in to C-SPAN 2 at 11:00am CT today to watch me be sworn-in for the 115th Congress.

I do solemnly swear that I will support and defend the Constitution of the United States against all enemies, foreign and domestic; that I will bear true faith and allegiance to the same; that I take this obligation freely, without any mental reservation or purpose of evasion; and that I will well and faithfully discharge the duties of the office on which I am about to enter: So help me God.

I am incredibly grateful for the honor to represent the state of Oklahoma as one of its United States Senators. The people of Oklahoma have entrusted me to serve in this capacity on their behalf, and I hope to make all Oklahomans proud of this office for the next six years. Today’s swearing-in is symbolic for me and my family for so many reasons, but also a powerful reminder that we live in a great democratic republic that is self-governed and led by the people. Any person, including someone like me who served in ministry for 22 years, can be chosen to serve in Congress.   This is a pivotal time for the United States of America, as our nation faces many threats and challenges. Our national security is at risk, our federal government is inefficient, debt is rising out-of-control, and our economy is sluggish. Too many families face poverty, the health care system is unaffordable, and basic freedoms are at risk. There is so much work to get done in this Congress, and I commit to serve diligently and faithfully every day.

Just a bit ago, the Senate voted to begin the process to repeal Obamacare. Oklahomans have seen first-hand the devastation caused by the impact of Obamacare. Last year, the Obama administration announced a 25 percent increase in premiums across the nation. The news for our state was much worse. Oklahoma will see a rise of 76 percent with only one health insurer to offer plans through the federal exchange in 2017. This will leave Oklahomans with no choice for their healthcare and devastatingly increased costs.   Today’s vote begins the legislative process to repeal Obamacare and implement a plan that is focused on putting control back into the hands of patients, families, and doctors. It’s time to move forward to repeal and replace Obamacare. It’s time to focus on a future of a healthy America.

In case you missed it, it was great to join the Exploring Energy Radio Show to talk about the new 115th Congress and the confirmation process in the Senate for Oklahoma Attorney General Scott Pruitt for EPA Administrator and other nominees. Listen to our conversation HERE:

It was a pleasure to meet with General John Kelly to learn more about his impressive military experience and his vision for the Department of Homeland Security. Our national security is a priority that we need to take very seriously. We need a strong leader at the Homeland Security Department, a person who will help protect America against terrorism and secure our borders.   General Kelly's background provides unique insight into some of the challenges the United States faces as it relates to terrorism, immigration, and drug trafficking. I look forward to his confirmation hearing, and I am optimistic that he will be confirmed.
The Joint Session of Congress to count the Electoral Votes will be starting shortly. TUNE IN to C-SPAN to watch: https://www.c-span.org/networks/

It is my honor to continue to serve as co-chairman of the Congressional Prayer Caucus and be a leader in the Senate for religious freedom. I am very glad to announce the new House co-chairman, Representative Mark Walker, who is committed to protecting the fundamental First Amendment right of free exercise of religion. Join me in congratulating Rep. Walker and praying for his continued leadership in this role.  Read more about Rep. Walker and the Congressional Prayer Caucus here:
Thank you to the men and women who put on a uniform every day and sacrifice of themselves and their families to protect and serve our community! We are grateful for your service.

I was very glad to sit down today with Congressman Mick Mulvaney, President-elect Donald Trump’s nominee to be the director of the Office of Management and Budget. Mick shares my commitment to address the debt and to reduce the burdensome regulations that plague US economic growth.  The nation’s $20 trillion debt, and the problems that come with it, is the single most important issue that faces our country’s future. We need someone like Mick to help root out government waste, reduce burdensome and stifling federal regulations, and address the structural issues with the national debt. Congress and the administration must work together to address these issues in a real and meaningful way. I look forward to Mick’s confirmation hearings, and I am encouraged that he will make it through the process.

The Intelligence Committee, of which I am a member, is holding a rare, open hearing starting in about 10 minutes at 12pm CT on Russian intelligence activities. Directors of National Intelligence, CIA, NSA, and FBI will be testifying before the committee. You can watch the hearing online HERE:

In case you missed it, I spoke with Directors of National Intelligence, CIA, NSA, and FBI at an Intelligence Committee hearing earlier on Russian hacking activities and the unclassified intelligence report put out over the weekend. I used my time to question our top Intelligence heads about whether Russia was successful in manipulating vote tallies, and how many other countries have been the target of Russia hacking. Watch my Q&A here:
We have started on the confirmation hearing for General Kelly as Secretary of the Department of Homeland Security in the Homeland Security Committee. You can watch the hearing LIVE here:

In case you missed it, I spoke with Gen. John Kelly, President-elect Trump's nominee for Secretary of the Department of Homeland Security, yesterday at his confirmation hearing. With all the instability around the world, we need a strong leader at the helm of DHS. Gen. Kelly’s background provides the essential experience needed to direct an agency that deals with immigration, cybersecurity, and national security issues. I will proudly support his nomination to be Secretary of the Department of Homeland Security.

In the midst of busy weeks in Washington like this one, it is great to be able to sit down and enjoy coffee and conversation with Oklahomans who have traveled up to DC during my weekly coffee hour, Java with James. Don't forget to reach out to my office if you are planning a trip and let us know when you will be in town. We'd love to have you stop by!

My office has just put out my 2016 annual activity report. We were able to accomplish a lot last year, and I'm looking forward to all this year has in store and continuing work on behalf of Oklahomans.

I talked with Lou Dobbs last night on Fox Business about many of the confirmation hearings going on in the Senate this week including General John Kelly, Senator Jeff Sessions, and Rex Tillerson, as well as President-elect Trump's press conference yesterday. Check out our conversation:

Mike Pompeo’s impressive resume, years of military and private-sector experience and service on the House Intelligence Committee, makes him a distinctively qualified candidate to lead the CIA. It speaks volumes that he has an excellent reputation both with his colleagues and with the men and women of the Intelligence Community. I respect Mike and know he will lead the Agency with honor, integrity, and with the commitment to protect our nation.

Early Wednesday, the Senate passed a budget resolution that begins the process to repeal and replace Obamacare. I support its repeal because the law has made health care very expensive and burdensome for a large number of Oklahoma families, businesses and charities. I understand the anxiety felt by some Oklahomans that are unsure and confused by the news and what’s happening in Washington, DC. This budget resolution vote does not mean that health insurance plans in the Obamacare exchange will go away immediately. In the coming months, Congress will debate and pass reforms that will provide a smooth transition to a better health care solution that leads to better coverage options for everyone. To stay up-to-date with current issues being debated in Congress, visit this webpage often, sign up for my e-newsletter, or contact my office anytime.  https://www.lankford.senate.gov/issues

I spoke with Lee Matthews on KTOK in Oklahoma City this morning about the activities in the Senate this week, including confirmation hearings and the process we started in repealing Obamacare. Listen HERE:

I was on Fox News this morning to talk about confirmation hearings going on in the Senate, including the nomination of Mike Pompeo to be CIA director, as well as President-elect Trump's cabinet picks diverging views on Russia.
Today we honor the life and legacy of the incomparable Dr. King. Be inspired today by his love and kindness for people and his courage and determination to keep moving forward.

We are truly blessed to live in a nation that recognizes and respects religious freedom. Join me today in celebrating National Religious Freedom Day and our fundamental right of free exercise of religion.
The tickets have arrived! We're ready to see all the Okies coming up for inauguration this week.

Great to meet with Dr. Ben Carson today to discuss his vision for the Department of Housing and Urban Development and its ability to help people. Dr. Carson’s focus is on transitioning HUD into an agency that helps people escape poverty, rather than just survive in it. Dr. Carson is a powerful personal example on how someone can rise out of poverty. His genuine love for people will serve the nation well in this position.

I am honored to introduce Attorney General Scott Pruitt at his confirmation hearing this morning before the Environment and Public Works Committee on his nomination to be the next EPA Administrator. The hearing begins at 9:00am CT and you can watch on C-SPAN 3 or online HERE:

Scott Pruitt is a friend. I have prayed with Scott. I have seen him struggle with hard decisions that affect our state’s future. I have seen him listen to people to try to learn all sides of an issue. And, I have seen him take difficult stands on matters of law. Scott Pruitt will make an excellent Administrator for the EPA, working hard for our nation’s present and for the future.

I am chairing a subcommittee hearing this morning on how federal regulations disproportionally impact small businesses. Testifying before the committee is Oklahoman and small business owner, Jerry Hietpas, President of the Action Safety Supply Company. You can tune in art 9:00am CT to watch the hearing LIVE:

Most people in the U.S. don't know that an American pastor is being imprisoned in Turkey unjustly. After living peacefully as a minister and humanitarian aid worker for 20 years, he was imprisoned in October based on unsubstantiated allegations. In December, I met with officials in Turkey about Andrew Brunson’s case, but the situation remains bleak. If Turkey continues to treat Americans this way, all trade deals and foreign aid with them should be reconsidered.  http://www.foxnews.com/opinion/2017/01/18/sen-lankford-imprisoned-pastor-in-turkey-must-be-released-immediately.html

It's been good to have so many Okies in Washington, DC for the 58th Presidential Inauguration. It was also great to meet Enid Buzz Owner Curtis Tucker, whose trip to DC was completely supported by the Enid community. Stay tuned for more photos and videos of the Inaugural experience tomorrow.   No matter who you voted for, it's pretty incredible to see our national peaceful transfer of power -- something that so many countries around the world could only dream about. We should not take this for granted.

It is an honor to be a part of this 58th Presidential Inauguration to officially swear-in the 45th President of the United States, Donald J. Trump. Today is a day that “we the people” come together to celebrate our democracy and a peaceful transfer of power.   Here is my view of #InaugurationDay.

Today is a truly historic event for our nation as we celebrate the Inauguration of the 45th President of the United States, Donald J. Trump and Vice President Mike Pence. Today affirms to the world that after a divisive election, the nation can move forward in an orderly and resilient way. I look forward to working with the new Administration to address the problems that Oklahoma and the American people sent us here to solve.

Today affirms to the world that after a divisive election, the nation can move forward in an orderly, resilient and powerful way. Americans have our differences, but we should always strive to be a more compassionate and unified nation. It's days like today that I am reminded that America is and always will be the greatest nation in the world.

This week we recognize and celebrate National School Choice Week. We should continue to support our public schools, but we should also support school choice for families who need it. I support School Choice because I believe every child in America deserves a quality education, no matter their zip code.

The American burying beetle may seem like a little problem, but it actually has a massive impact on our economy, placing unnecessary regulations and restrictions on our local communities. Check out this article on the recent report put out by the Government Accountability Office about the American burying beetle. This report truly reinforces the need for oversight of the Fish and Wildlife Service and reinforces my opinion that the beetle should be removed from the endangered species list.

TUNE IN: Many of you have commented on this page about Obamacare and its impact on your family. I hear you & appreciate your thoughts. I will be speaking on the Senate floor today at approximately 5:00pm CT to discuss the process to repeal and replace Obamacare. Watch the Senate floor live on C-SPAN2.

Many Oklahomans are concerned about the impact of Obamacare on their families. Many of you are also concerned about what a replacement plan would mean for your family. Tonight, I spoke on the Senate floor on why we must move forward with repealing and replacing the law. Oklahomans deserve a smooth transition to a more personalized, patient-centered health care system that is affordable for everyone. That is what I will be fighting for.

As we prepare for The March for Life this week, I want to encourage those participating all over the nation. We speak for those who cannot yet speak, we march for those who cannot yet march, and we will continue to fight to defend the right to life at every turn.

It was incredible to witness today the compassion and dedication of the pro-life movement at The March for Life. This is what the pro-life generation looks like and they stand eager to defend the dignity of all human life. We've made tremendous progress on life issues but we still have much to do. Let's get to work and stand for life together.

As leaders, we have a responsibility to secure the homeland. The executive action issued Friday is a 90-day pause and reevaluation of the screening process for individuals traveling from seven war-torn nations, and a 120-day pause for the refugee resettlement program. It is not a ban on Muslims or a permanent change in immigration policy. However, this executive action has some unintended consequences that were not well thought out. I encourage the president's staff to evaluate American policy with an eye on both security and compassion for the refugees fleeing the terrors of war and persecution. For decades, our resettlement program has maintained a very extensive multi-year screening process for refugees from all over the world. There are unique challenges when you accept refugees from countries like Syria and Yemen, but our American security and intelligence communities are the best in the world. America can have strong homeland security and uphold our foundational values of religious freedom and refuge for the persecuted. These goals are not mutually exclusive. We should also encourage, not discourage, people who have gone through the legal visa and immigration process. America has always welcomed people from different walks of life, religions and countries, and we should continue doing so.

Yesterday, I joined Senator Joni Ernst to introduce the Protect Funding for Women’s Health Care Act to redirect taxpayer funds from Planned Parenthood to other eligible women's health care providers that don't perform abortions.  Planned Parenthood receives millions in private donation money every year--there is no reason for a private non-governmental organization, like Planned Parenthood, to receive $500 million a year in taxpayer money.  This bill will protect federal funding for health services for women, including diagnostic laboratory and radiology services, well-child care, prenatal and postnatal care, immunizations, cervical and breast cancer screenings, and more, ensuring there is no reduction in overall federal funding available to support women’s health.  Check out my website for more information:

It is encouraging to see the Trump administration prioritize work on the regulatory state in his first few weeks in office. Now is the time to pull back on over-burdensome federal regulations through executive actions, but we must also pursue regulatory improvements through the legislative process.   Requiring agencies to identify existing regulations for repeal before they promulgate new regulations is a successful practice to ensure cumulative regulatory burden is properly controlled. We have got to cut back on the pace, intrusiveness, and sheer burden of regulations that has stalled job creation and economic growth.

Neil Gorsuch has served Oklahoma well on the 10th Circuit Court & he'll be great for the highest court in the land. We now have a nominee in Judge Gorsuch who has an impressive record of interpreting the law without trying to legislate from the bench. I am especially impressed by his legal opinions on federal regulatory interpretation and constitutional balance of powers. It is particularly noteworthy that Judge Gorsuch was confirmed unanimously in 2006 by the Senate to the 10th Circuit, even receiving support from then-Senators Joe Biden, Hillary Clinton, Barack Obama and Chuck Schumer. Neil Gorsuch is an excellent pick for the Supreme Court and I look forward to him being confirmed.

I wanted to take a little time to talk about President Trump's Supreme Court nominee, Judge Neil Gorsuch, and this important moment for us as a nation. As always, if you ever have questions or want more information, please feel free to reach out to my office. We are here to serve you.
Introducing the Free Speech Fairness Act with Representative Steve Scalise and the Family Research Council.

I'm very proud today to introduce the Free Speech Fairness Act, to fix the Johnson Amendment and give nonprofits and houses of worship the freedom to speak about government or electoral activity without the threat of retribution from the IRS. The First Amendment right of free speech and right to practice any faith, or no faith, are foundational American values that must extend to everyone, whether they are a pastor, social worker or any charity employee or volunteer.  Read more about my fix to the Johnson Amendment HERE:

I sat in amazement this morning at the National Prayer Breakfast, at how one thing could bring such a large, diverse group of people together: prayer. This one very basic idea unites us, regardless of who we pray to or how we pray. Prayer unites us in making us more compassionate, more forgiving, more loving, and I'm grateful to live in a nation that protects prayer as free exercise of religion.

I will support Betsy DeVos for Education Secretary for one main reason—she has expressed her absolute commitment to transfer more control of education policy from Washington, DC to states, parents, and local leaders.   Throughout my time in Congress, I have seen the dangers of a centralized, one-size-fits-all bureaucracy that assumes every child learns the same way and requires the same school model. Schools in Oklahoma don’t need to be run like schools in New York or Oregon or any other state. I want Oklahomans, not bureaucrats in Washington, to address our education needs, because they can make education decisions that are best for Oklahoma students, teachers, and families.   Betsy DeVos has served in roles throughout her life that empower students and families, especially students in poverty and those with special needs. Ms. DeVos is a non-traditional selection for Education Secretary, but there is no question that she has spent her life working to improve education in America.

The stall tactics being used in the Senate to delay confirmation votes are out of control. President Trump should be allowed to put his cabinet together just like republicans allowed President Obama to put his cabinet together. Let's let President Trump get his team together so they can get to work for the American people.

The First Amendment right of free speech and right to practice any faith, or no faith, are foundational American values that must extend to everyone, no matter if they’re a Jewish rabbi, a Buddhist monk, a Baptist pastor or a Muslim imam.  Every American should be able to speak freely about their conscience and convictions, no matter what their job is. If you agree with that simple statement, we welcome your support of the Free Speech Fairness Act.

You deserve to know how your tax dollars are spent at federal agencies. My Taxpayers Right to Know Act requires every federal agency to provide taxpayers details of costs and performance metrics, basically an annual report card, for all of its programs. When passed and signed into law, this will be a big step toward greater transparency and accountability.

No matter who you voted for, the election is over. It’s time to move on. President Trump deserves the right to build his cabinet team just as President Obama did. The #HistoricObstruction by Senate Democrats is wasting time that should be spent on important work for the American people.
The numbers speak for themselves. Delaying the inevitable does not help the American people.

My colleague, Senate Democratic Leader Chuck Schumer, is under an immense amount of pressure from the Democratic base who are still upset about the results of the election. They’re calling for Democrats to obstruct and use meaningless procedural hurdles to delay the work of the Senate at any cost. I understand the frustration that many Americans feel about the state of politics today. But the obstruction is only delaying the inevitable, giving liberals a false hope, and preventing us from working on very important issues like debt reduction, health care improvements, tax reform, regulatory reform, and national security.
TUNE IN: I'll be on Fox News' Americas Newsroom at 8:40am CT to discuss the 9th Circuit's ruling against the President's temporary travel ban.
We as Americans don't have to agree on everything. We can disagree and we can disagree strongly. It doesn't have to be personal.

Most Americans missed this, but my colleague Sen. Marco Rubio gave a really thoughtful speech about the need for civility in our country's politically discourse. We can very strongly disagree with each other, but we can remain personally respectful and not call each other names. I call on all elected leaders in Washington to lead the nation in turning down the volume.   If you have an extra 8 minutes today, please watch this video:  https://youtu.be/J8AiJlYoUo8

Americans are divided on the topic of abortion, but one thing we should all be able to agree on is that no one should be forced to participate in it if it violates a deeply held religious or moral belief. This is why I introduced the Conscience Protection Act of 2017.

Last night's news regarding General Mike Flynn is concerning. The position of National Security Advisor is critical to ensuring the various agencies are cooperating effectively in matters of national security. Gen. Flynn resigned because he lost the trust of the President and the White House. The Senate Intelligence Committee, which I serve on, has already started an investigation into Russia’s attempts to interfere in the 2016 elections, including potential links between the presidential campaigns and Russian Government. The investigation will be thorough and deliberate, and we will follow the evidence wherever it leads.

Years ago, Congress gave the authority to the president to pay court-ordered payments to litigants without requesting each payment individually. But, after the Obama Administration used the federal Judgement Fund to pay $1.7 billion to Iran on the same day Iran returned four hostages, and they attempted to use the Judgement Fund to pay Obamacare subsidies to insurance companies—it is clear that the Judgement Fund needs more oversight. It was never intended to be a pot of money for an administration to use at their discretion.   Today I introduced the Judgment Fund Transparency and Terrorism Financing Prevention Act to provide transparency and accountability & prohibits taxpayer-funded payments to foreign nations that have state-sponsored terrorism.    Read more about my bill here:

I was glad to be able to speak with Judge Gorsuch about his qualifications to serve on the Court. We discussed his judicial philosophy, as well as the need for the Courts to respect the separation of powers between the federal government, states, and the three equal branches of government. I enjoyed our conversation, and I look forward to his confirmation hearing.

In case you missed it, I spoke with Brian Kilmeade on Fox News Radio this morning about intelligence matters including the resignation of General Flynn as Nation Security Advisor and the Senate Intelligence Committee's investigation into Russian interference in the election. Listen to our conversation here:

TUNE IN: I will speak on the Senate floor today in a few moments (approximately 5:10pm CT) about the confirmation of Scott Pruitt to be the EPA Administrator. You can watch the Senate floor live on C-SPAN2.

Here is my floor speech tonight about Scott Pruitt's confirmation for EPA Administrator. The misinformation being spread about Oklahoma's environmental quality, our oil and gas industry, and Scott's job as Attorney General is startling. I had to set the record straight.

In a bipartisan vote, the Senate just confirmed Scott Pruitt as the next Administrator of the EPA. Rather than twist environmental laws to invent new powers for the EPA, Scott will enforce existing law and ensure that we protect the environment, and also protect family budgets. The federal government must improve efficiencies across agencies, especially the agency that ensures clean air, clean drinking water, and a healthy environment. Scott will do this job well, and I look forward to continuing our work together for the future of the nation as he leads the EPA.

As this year’s CPAC conference convenes this week in Washington, DC, I am reminded of the great honor it was to speak about religious freedom at the conference last year. Our nation must support religious freedom for all faiths, and all people who wish to live their faith peacefully. We must also support the right to have no faith at all. As a conservative, I believe we must be supportive of this basic First Amendment right.
It was great to tour the new GE research facility in Oklahoma City and get a chance to visit with employees about regulations and issues important to them and the work being done at GE.

I was honored today to stand with Senator Matthews, Mayor Bynum, and an incredible group of leaders in North Tulsa to announce the formation of the 1921 Tulsa Race Riot Centennial Commission. As the entire nation will turn to Tulsa and Oklahoma in a few years, this Commission will be at the forefront of telling the story of the Race Riot in 2021.   The 1921 Race Riot is a dark story of death and destruction, but it is also a story of resilience and reconciliation. However, this story is not over. We must stand together to continue to pursue reconciliation until this region is economically revitalized.
I'm speaking now on a panel at the Heritage Foundation on physician-assisted suicide. You can watch the panel discussion online HERE:

Physician-assisted suicide is an issue that I come to with a unique perspective and beg the question: how can we honor and have compassion for every human life, at every stage, no matter what background they come from. The slippery slope ramification of legalizing this has a major impact on the mdeical profession, as well as how our society treats the disabled, the poor and the elderly. I encourage you to watch my opening statement from a panel discussion on physician-assisted suicide today:
I just did a TV interview with Lou Dobbs about the President’s upcoming Joint Address to Congress (8pm CT). I want to hear from you.... what do you want to hear the President talk about tonight?
Headed over to the Joint Session to hear President Trump's speech

I applaud President Trump's call for national unity. I agree that we must pursue regulatory reform, tax reform and the repeal and replacement of the Affordable Care Act. In 2016, the economy only grew by 1.6% GDP, the lowest since 2011. President Trump can take executive actions, but you can’t do long-term change without the legislative branch of government. America must come together as a nation, and the federal gov't also must do a better job working together on behalf of the American people.

We had a packed house this morning at my weekly coffee hour for Oklahomans visiting DC. I'm always glad to connect with Oklahomans during busy weeks in Washington to have conversation over a cup of coffee. If you are ever planning a trip up to the Capitol, please plan to stop by the office.

I discussed a lot of topics on CNN’s Situation Room with Wolf Blitzer tonight -- including Yemen, North Korea, and national security. We also talked about the need for immigration reform, and what a package of bills could look like. We can’t just give blanket citizenship to people who are here illegally, but we must look at ways to strengthen border security, modernize our visa process, and give certainty to people brought to America as children.
Congratulations to our new Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, Dr. Ben Carson. Confirmed by the Senate this morning in a bipartisan vote, I know Dr. Carson will lead well at HUD.

**Before commenting on this page, please watch the video first and hear everything I have to say.  I just spoke on Fox Business about Attorney General Jeff Sessions meeting with the Russian ambassador last year. There seems to be dramatic overreaction in trying to paint every person in the Trump Administration as secret KGB, but the facts do not support that. Everybody needs to step back off the ledge and keep this in context. I met with ambassadors this week. That is part of the job of a United States Senator. Let’s get the facts out and deal with facts rather than random accusations. A call for resignation is ridiculous.

My office is still accepting applications for internships in my Tulsa, OKC, and Washington, DC offices for this Summer. If you or someone you know is interested in this opportunity, please check out my website for more information on how to apply:

This afternoon, I appeared on Fox News to discuss the President's wiretapping accusation, if a Special Prosecutor is needed to investigate Russian interference in our election, and instability in the Korean peninsula. I have no evidence that President Obama ordered a wiretap on Trump's campaign telephones.

The American people elect representatives in Congress to oversee classified intelligence processes, protect your security, and guard classified information. I urge all Americans to have patience with the Intelligence Committee’s thorough investigation into Russian interference with the elections. The ability for our intelligence processes and methods to remain classified is extremely important. In due time, a full non-partisan report will be available for the American people to see.  However today, the Appropriations subcommittee on State and Foreign Operations is holding a public hearing on Russian policies and engagement with other European countries. You can watch the hearing online starting at 1:15pm CT:

Great to have the Norman Chamber in DC this week. I stopped by after votes this afternoon in the Capitol to talk about tax reform, the federal budget, the next steps for Obamacare, and nominations before the Senate.

Tonight, I appeared on PBS Newshour to discuss national security and intelligence issues, including the congressional investigation into Russian interference with U.S. elections, and today's news about a Wikileaks classified information breach.

I'm saddened to learn of the passing of Mike McCarville. Mike was an investigator, communicator, and he had a passion for people and politics. He loved his state and its people, and he will be missed by me and my family. My prayers are with his loved ones and many friends.

I introduced a package of regulatory reform bills today to make the rulemaking process more efficient by requiring earlier public engagement for proposed rules, curbing the abuse of agency guidance documents, and forcing agencies to analyze the total impact regulations have on small businesses.   No matter who the president is, the federal rulemaking process needs greater transparency and accountability. Check out my website for more information:

Tonight, I spoke on the Senate floor in favor of a bill to overturn the Obama administration Dept of Education "accountability and state plans" regulation (H.Res.57). In December 2015, Congress passed and President Obama signed into law the Every Student Succeeds Act to fix No Child Left Behind, but the Dept of Education manipulated the bill's regulations to put more responsibilities on teachers, and take away more education management from Oklahoma. This regulation is bad and must be overturned.   Before you comment, please watch my remarks.

I am chairing a hearing this morning in my subcommittee on Regulatory Affairs and Federal Management on federal agency use of science in the rulemaking process. It is a main focus of my subcommittee to provide oversight and find ways to improve transparency and accountability in the federal government. Watch the hearing online HERE:

I spoke about the wildfires in NW Oklahoma this morning on the radio in Woodward. The devastation so many are facing is heartbreaking, but know that help is on the way and we are all praying for you. As the Senate wraps up votes today, I'll fly back to Oklahoma late tonight and I hope to spend the day tomorrow in Woodward, Beaver, and Harper counties.
Great to catch up with some extremely bright young student leaders from Northeastern State University during their trip to the Capitol earlier today.

All of Oklahoma stands with our friends and neighbors in northwest Oklahoma battling the devastating wildfires—you are not alone. A number of fire relief resources have already been made available as you walk through a literal firestorm.   Oklahomans that want to help can donate: hay, water, food, and additional items to support those in Harper County, Woodward County, Beaver County and the surrounding areas.   Senator Inhofe and I are working with the USDA, relief organizations, and community leaders to provide a list of resources that are available to help. Please check out this list of resources and do not hesitate to reach out to my office if you have any questions:
Senator Inhofe and I are participating in a press conference this morning in Woodward on the wildfires in NW Oklahoma.

I toured the damage from the wildfires in Northwest Oklahoma this morning and had a chance to speak with some of the firefighters, first responders, volunteers, and Oklahomans who have lost a lot from the destruction. It is devastating to see such wreckage, but it is also encouraging to see a community come together to support those who are hurting. There is no shortage of ways to help our our fellow Oklahomans and if you are in need of help, please do not hesitate to contact my office. We have a long road ahead, but we can walk through it together.
In case you missed it, I spoke with The Pat Campbell Show in Tulsa this morning about the process to repeal and replace Obamacare as well as the House's American Health Care Act. Listen HERE:

President Trump is taking some major steps in the right direction to address duplication and waste in the executive branch. As the Administration begins to reorganize, I encourage them to take a look at my "Federal Fumbles" report to see some areas that need to be addressed.

Just left the White House for a meeting with Vice President Pence and staff. In December, as Congress considered the Continuing Resolution, I argued that enacting another CR would further discourage Congress from appropriating in regular order, and would push last year’s budgeting process to this year. I could not support that and I did not.   There are two options to fund our government right now: pass a Continuing Resolution that continues to fund the government at the spending level of the last omnibus, or support the new omnibus, which funds the government for the rest of the year with much needed reforms to reduce spending, reductions in unnecessary regulations, and more transparency. Neither option is ideal, but there is no question that the latest appropriations bill is better than last year.  As I support this path to fund the government until September 2017, I strongly urge Congress to reform the current budget process and produce a balanced budget. Since 1974, the budget process has worked as intended only four times; in fact, Congress has passed a continuing resolution 173 times. This is not a political issue, it’s a process issue, and Congress needs to fix the broken process. We must continue to work to reform the budget process to address the most predictable crisis in our history, rather than putting off this crisis until later. HEALTHCARE UPDATE: As promised, Senate Republicans have allowed an open debate and amendment process, over the last 48 hours, to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act. This afternoon the Senate voted on an amendment that would create a government run ‘single-payer’ healthcare system, like the one Bernie Sanders has advocated for. The legislative text of the amendment was the exact same as the “Medicare for All” bill (HR 676) already introduced in the House. It’s called ‘single payer’ because it would create one payer, or insurer - the federal government.   I opposed this amendment because I think it would not just double-down, but triple-down on many of the problems of Obamacare. Nearly every health-care decision could be decided by a federal bureaucrat in Washington, DC. Yes, there are many countries around the world that have similar healthcare models, like the United Kingdom, France, and Canada… but it is nearly indisputable that the American medical industry is still one of the most respected and advanced in the world, so much so that many people come to the U.S. from around the world for the best healthcare. And oh, by the way, a single payer system would require the government to significantly increase income taxes to pay for it.   Thankfully, this amendment failed by a bipartisan vote of 0-57, with 43 senators responding “present.” That’s right. 43 Senators were there, but refused to take a position on a bill that has over 150 Democrat co-sponsors in the House of Representatives.   Later tonight, the Senate will have many more amendment votes until after midnight. The losers in the failed vote last night were not politicians in Washington DC, they were people sitting at kitchen tables across America trying to make sense of the chaos of their finances and their government.

There has been a lot of confusion about what’s happening with the federal Children’s Health Insurance Program, also called CHIP. Jimmy Kimmel discussed it on his late-night show last night, so I wanted to clear some things up.   HERE ARE THE FACTS: Created in 1997, CHIP is a healthcare federal block grant program to the states to provide health insurance for low-income children who don’t qualify for Medicaid. This CHIP block grant is administered by the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) and must be matched with state dollars. In Oklahoma, approximately 180,000 children benefit from this block grant program. On October 1, 2017, the federal funding authorization for the program expired, however, there is enough money in the program to fund it until March 2018 for most states, including Oklahoma.    I want to be clear: I fully support the CHIP program. Unfortunately, there are some serious management inefficiencies, fraud, and waste within the CHIP program that need to be addressed. I am eager to see some fiscally responsible and sustainable reforms made to the program so that it’s strengthened for the families who rely on it and the funding for the program can go undisturbed for years to come. Children and families are counting on us to put in safeguards now so that cuts are not necessary in the future. Although the funding for this program lasts until next Spring, I want a solution sooner rather than later. I don’t sit on the committee working on CHIP reforms (Senate Finance Committee), but I am working with my colleagues to ensure that children continue to get the support they need, and I will keep you updated in the days ahead.

I’ve received some questions about net neutrality this month, so I wanted to explain what’s happening. Today, the Federal Communications Commission, not Congress, voted on a plan to roll back regulations that create more government control of the internet. The regulations were put in place in 2015 under the President Obama administration to have greater control on internet provider management and access, but they ended up hurting broadband investment and innovation. Since 2015, the extra regulations have resulted in less broadband investment in rural areas of Oklahoma, which is a big problem for many rural states.    Look, there is often an appropriate need for regulations, but I have always preferred less federal regulation, not more. Internet providers will still have strong consumer protections and transparency requirements to maintain. The exaggerated doomsday scenarios about net neutrality have been over-the-top. Before these 2015 regulations, the internet thrived under both Democratic and Republican administrations. America is a world leader in internet technology—a position we can and should maintain in the future. Moving forward, we must be cautious about issuing preemptive regulations and examine the market need for such rules. And the American people, through Congress, should make these types of decisions, not a federal bureaucracy.
